content.text: This document provides an overview of septic shock, a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's response to an infection injures its own tissues and organs. It is a subset of sepsis with a higher risk of mortality.

Septic shock is characterized by persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 65 mm Hg or higher and a serum lactate level greater than 2 mmol/L (>18 mg/dL) despite adequate volume resuscitation.
Management focuses on early recognition, rapid administration of antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, and vasopressor support. Source control is also a critical component of management.
